By James Bithell

Fiona Wong explores how art has been used in therapy as well as commercial development through books

By James Bithell

Amelie Rothwell discusses the history of dance and the footprint that is has left on our art and popular culture

By James Bithell

Jess Buck explores the continued relevance of Roald Dahl's best loved character and why she's a feminist icon

Fiona Wong explores whether the photo-based social media app has a positive effect on the art scene

By Hope Jennings-Grounds

Hope Jennings-Grounds delves into the way that mental health is being portrayed within contemporary poetry

Stella Newing describes her experience volunteering at a literature festival

By Saskia Starritt

In the second of three articles about York Theatre Royal's production of new play Minefield, Carla Torres interviewed the other members of the full cast.

Theatre Interview: The Cast Of Minefield (Part I)

In the first of three articles about York Theatre Royal's production of new play Minefield, Carla Torres interviewed three of its war veteran cast members.

Arts Report: Lucy Worsley on 'Jane Austen At Home'

Lucy Worsley is touring the UK to celebrate the release of her new book on the life of Jane Austen. We sent Ruth Lee to report on what she said.

Dramasoc's Spring Season Announced

It's getting very political down at The Drama Barn next Spring as Charlie Ralph gives us a full rundown of next semester's shows.

The Frantic Art Of Storytelling

Frantic Assembly are one of the most exciting theatre groups in Britain. Before their visit to York next week, Rachael Cheesman recounts their history and unique style.

Drawing the Best out of Things

Lara Medlam talks to illustrator Izzy Johns about pens, paper, imagination and the challenges faced by fledgling artists

A One-Woman Review Mission

Eliza Hunton on her experience of solo Edinburgh fringe shows as a solo reviewer

P-P-P-Pick up a Penguin

Lara Medlam considers Penguin's rich design history and wonders if sometimes it's worth judging a book by its cover

Cheap Laughs - Comedy Clubs at the Fringe

The Edinburgh Fringe's comedy output is exciting, vibrant - and enormous. Andrew Young looks back over his Fringe experience and offers some sage advice on how to make the most of the many laughs on offer

Printing the Floating World

Dan Hall talks to Percy Barkes about the finer points of Japanese prints and the resurgence of Watanabe Setei

Shakespeare in York

Megan Johnston explores the marvels of the York International Shakespeare Festival

Tradition Goes Pop

Lara Medlam revels in the electric style and vivid colours of Japanese psych-pop artist Tadanori Yokoo

Resolution of Sound

Lara Medlam speaks to Samra Mayana - one of the organisers behind an innovative evening that fuses music, poetry and art

S-tree-t Art

Lea Marrazo examines the Roman street art renaissance, led by eco-artist Andrea Gandini

Minimalism is More

In the wake of York Theatre Royal's production of The Machine Stops, Eliza Hunton unpicks the virtues of simple sets

Hes Eastern Promises

Jack Flower considers the relative architectural merits of Hes East and West. How will they be viewed in 50 years?

Cast a Spell on You

Podcasts may be out of sight but they're not out of mind - Lara Medlam considers their inconspicuous rise

Flourishing in Publishing

Eliza Hunton talks to publishing veteran Lorna Petty about the best ways to break into this competitive industry

Art Grows on You

Lara Medlam talks to artist Mellissa Fisher about her experimental choice of medium: 'bacteria'

What are they Laughing at?

Eliza Hunton wonders if kids and the authors that write for them are finding the right things funny

Affairs of the Heart

Lara Medlam examines the elusive origins of love's greatest symbol

There's More than Meets the Ear

Lara Medlam highlights the innovative but overlooked spirit of album cover design
